facts: A magnet for hummingbirds, especially in late summer.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free, watch for root rot in wet soil.
growingTip: Prefers full sun and tolerates drought once established.

facts: A consistent bloomer that provides color for months.
pestsDiseases: Resistant to most pests; can get powdery mildew.
growingTip: Deadhead regularly to encourage continuous blooming.

facts: The black calyces (the part that holds the flower) give this plant its dramatic look.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free.
growingTip: Spreads by runners, so give it room to grow or plant in a container.

facts: Part of the 'Wish' series of Salvias, known for their vibrant colors and long bloom season.
pestsDiseases: Generally robust and healthy.
growingTip: A portion of the sales from this plant supports the Make-A-Wish foundation.

facts: A sterile hybrid, meaning it won't self-sow in the garden.
pestsDiseases: Very few problems.
growingTip: Can be pruned back hard in spring to encourage bushier growth.

facts: A compact variety perfect for containers and smaller garden spaces.
pestsDiseases: Good disease resistance.
growingTip: Attracts hummingbirds and butterflies with its bicolored flowers.

facts: A workhorse in the garden, producing flower spikes all season long and is deer resistant.
pestsDiseases: Very low maintenance and trouble-free.
growingTip: Cut back after flowering to promote a second flush of blooms.

facts: A California native. The entire plant is highly aromatic, releasing a classic sage scent.
pestsDiseases: Very drought tolerant; susceptible to root rot in wet conditions.
growingTip: Requires excellent drainage and minimal summer water once established.

facts: The leaves have a pleasant anise or licorice scent and are drought tolerant.
pestsDiseases: Resistant to deer; watch for powdery mildew in humid conditions.
growingTip: Do not over-fertilize, as it can lead to weak stems.

facts: A more compact version of traditional Agastache, great for smaller gardens.
pestsDiseases: Good air circulation helps prevent fungal issues.
growingTip: Perfect for front-of-border planting or in containers.

facts: Known for its strikingly deep blue flowers and contrasting bronze-tinted leaves.
pestsDiseases: Virtually pest and disease free.
growingTip: Prefers cooler weather; cut back in mid-summer if leggy to encourage new growth.

facts: A trailing lobelia variety perfect for hanging baskets and containers, featuring bright blue flowers with distinctive white eyes.
pestsDiseases: Virtually pest and disease free.
growingTip: Excellent for hanging baskets. Cut back in mid-summer if leggy to encourage new growth and continued blooming.

facts: A unique pink-flowered lobelia that performs well in partial shade, offering a softer color palette for shaded gardens and containers.
pestsDiseases: Virtually pest and disease free.
growingTip: Excellent for shade gardens and containers. Benefits from consistent moisture and protection from hot afternoon sun.

facts: Also known as Tulsi, this sacred basil is revered in Hindu tradition and prized for its medicinal properties and spiritual significance.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. May get aphids or spider mites in dry conditions.
growingTip: Pinch flowers to keep leaves tender. Harvest leaves regularly for tea and medicinal use.

facts: An ornamental basil variety with dark purple stems and flowers, creating a magical appearance in herb gardens and borders.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. May get aphids or spider mites in dry conditions.
growingTip: Excellent for ornamental use. Pinch flowers to maintain bushy growth or let bloom for pollinator attraction.

facts: Also known as cockscomb, these flowers have unique, intricate shapes.
pestsDiseases: Susceptible to root rot in wet soils.
growingTip: Thrives in heat and humidity. Great as a dried flower.

facts: A compact groundcover morning glory that produces masses of blue-violet trumpet flowers without the aggressive spreading habit.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. May get spider mites in hot, dry conditions.
growingTip: Excellent for rock gardens, containers, and slopes. Drought tolerant once established.

facts: A trailing perennial morning glory that forms a carpet of blue trumpet flowers, perfect for slopes and rock gardens.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. May get spider mites in hot, dry conditions.
growingTip: Excellent for erosion control on slopes. Trim back in late winter to maintain shape.

facts: An easy-to-grow flower that attracts many pollinators.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, Aster yellows.
growingTip: Tolerates poor soil. Do not over-fertilize, which produces foliage at the expense of flowers.

facts: A stunning delphinium series with unique bicolored flowers featuring lavender petals with bright yellow centers, creating an illuminated effect.
pestsDiseases: Crown rot, powdery mildew, aphids. Needs good air circulation.
growingTip: Requires cool, moist conditions. Cut back after first bloom for second flowering. Stake tall varieties.

facts: A seed-grown variety that produces a stunning mix of warm colors on every plant.
pestsDiseases: Japanese beetles, leaf spot. Good air circulation is key.
growingTip: Drought tolerant once established. Leave seed heads for winter bird feeding.
bloomColor: Mix of Red, Orange, Yellow, and Pink

facts: A classic purple coneflower with large, rosy-purple petals and prominent dark orange cones that attract butterflies and birds.
pestsDiseases: Generally disease resistant. May get powdery mildew in humid conditions.
growingTip: Deadhead spent flowers to encourage more blooms, or leave for birds to enjoy the seeds.

facts: Extremely drought and heat tolerant, making it perfect for tough, sunny spots.
pestsDiseases: No serious pests. Root rot in heavy, wet soil.
growingTip: Thrives on neglect. Deadheading prolongs bloom time.

facts: Produces multiple flowers per stalk, unlike single-stem varieties.
pestsDiseases: Birds and squirrels may eat seeds. Moths can be an issue.
growingTip: May require staking if it grows very tall.

facts: A hardy native wildflower that produces masses of bright yellow daisy-like flowers, perfect for xeriscaping and natural gardens.
pestsDiseases: Very disease resistant. Occasionally bothered by aphids.
growingTip: Extremely drought tolerant once established. Cut back in late fall for tidier appearance.

facts: The most fragrant and cold-hardy lavender variety, prized for its essential oils and culinary uses.
pestsDiseases: Very pest resistant. Root rot in wet soils is the main concern.
growingTip: Prune after flowering to maintain shape. Avoid overwatering and heavy, clay soils.

facts: A vigorous herb in the mint family with a delightful lemon scent, used for teas and natural pest deterrent.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. Can be invasive if not contained.
growingTip: Pinch flowers to keep leaves tender. Contains spreading by growing in pots or using barriers.

facts: A member of the mint family, it's a favorite of hummingbirds and bees.
pestsDiseases: Prone to powdery mildew; ensure good air circulation.
growingTip: Spreads by rhizomes; divide clumps every few years to control spread.

facts: A California native with aromatic foliage and clusters of tubular lavender flowers that attract hummingbirds and butterflies.
pestsDiseases: Very disease resistant. Avoid overwatering to prevent root rot.
growingTip: Extremely drought tolerant once established. Prune lightly after flowering to maintain shape.

facts: A scented geranium with delicate, finely-cut foliage that releases a citrus fragrance when touched, producing lovely lavender-pink flowers.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. Watch for aphids and whiteflies in greenhouse conditions.
growingTip: Pinch regularly to maintain bushy growth. Bring indoors before first frost in colder climates.

facts: A compact scented geranium with orange-citrus fragrant foliage and delicate pale pink flowers, perfect for containers.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. Watch for aphids and whiteflies in greenhouse conditions.
growingTip: Excellent for containers. Pinch to maintain compact shape. Overwinter indoors in cold climates.

facts: A beautiful hybrid penstemon with tubular lavender-blue flowers that are irresistible to hummingbirds and beneficial insects.
pestsDiseases: Generally disease resistant. Avoid overwatering to prevent root rot.
growingTip: Cut back after flowering to encourage second bloom. Very drought tolerant once established.

facts: One of the most vibrant and true-blue flowers available.
pestsDiseases: Root rot in wet winter soils.
growingTip: Needs sharp drainage, especially in winter. Often short-lived but worth it.

facts: A unique Rudbeckia with stunning deep red blooms instead of the typical yellow.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, powdery mildew.
growingTip: Deadhead to prolong blooming, but leave some seeds for birds.

facts: A compact version of the Mexican marigold with intensely fragrant foliage and continuous golden blooms that attract butterflies.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. May get spider mites in hot, dry conditions.
growingTip: Pinch flowers to maintain compact shape. Excellent for containers and borders.

facts: A low-growing, mat-forming thyme that releases a wonderful fragrance when walked on, perfect for pathways and rock gardens.
pestsDiseases: Very disease resistant. Root rot in wet soils.
growingTip: Extremely drought tolerant. Trim lightly after flowering to maintain dense growth.

facts: Its tall, airy stems create a see-through effect in the garden, attracting butterflies.
pestsDiseases: Generally disease and pest free.
growingTip: Readily self-seeds, so you'll have new plants each year.

facts: A tall perennial with impressive spikes of blue to purple flowers that provide excellent vertical interest in the garden.
pestsDiseases: Generally disease resistant. May get powdery mildew in humid conditions.
growingTip: Cut back after first flush of blooms for second flowering. May need staking in windy areas.

facts: A reliable, compact perennial with dense spikes of blue-purple flowers that bloom for months, perfect for borders.
pestsDiseases: Very disease resistant. Occasionally bothered by aphids.
growingTip: Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming. Very low maintenance.

facts: Attracts beneficial insects like ladybugs and lacewings that prey on pests.
pestsDiseases: Powdery mildew, rust. Can spread aggressively.
growingTip: Tolerates poor, dry soils. Cut back after flowering to prevent flopping.

facts: A soft-colored yarrow variety that attracts beneficial insects like ladybugs and lacewings while providing gentle pastel color.
pestsDiseases: Powdery mildew, rust. Can spread aggressively.
growingTip: Tolerates poor, dry soils. Cut back after flowering to prevent flopping and encourage second bloom.

facts: Known as one of the ultimate bee plants, this California native produces intense electric blue flowers that are irresistible to native bees.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest and disease free.
growingTip: Direct sow in fall for spring blooms. Self-seeds readily in suitable climates.

facts: A compact African daisy with pristine white flowers that bloom continuously from spring to fall, perfect for containers and borders.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. May get aphids in greenhouse conditions.
growingTip: Deadhead regularly for continuous blooms. Treat as annual in colder climates.

facts: An excellent dry bean for soups, holding its shape well.
pestsDiseases: Mexican bean beetles, bacterial blight.
growingTip: Provide a tall, sturdy trellis for this pole bean variety.

facts: An heirloom pole bean with distinctive purple-streaked pods that are tender and flavorful when harvested young.
pestsDiseases: Mexican bean beetles, bacterial blight.
growingTip: Provide tall, sturdy support. Harvest pods when young and tender for best flavor.

facts: An extraordinarily rare heirloom bean discovered in a cave, representing 1500 years of genetic preservation and cultural heritage.
pestsDiseases: Mexican bean beetles, bacterial blight.
growingTip: Save seeds carefully to preserve this ancient variety. Handle with reverence for its historical significance.

facts: A compact bush variety of the famous Blue Lake bean, perfect for small gardens and container growing.
pestsDiseases: Mexican bean beetles, bacterial blight.
growingTip: No staking required. Harvest regularly to keep plants producing tender pods.

facts: The classic pole bean variety prized for its tender, stringless pods and extended harvest period throughout the summer.
pestsDiseases: Mexican bean beetles, bacterial blight.
growingTip: Provide sturdy 6-8 foot poles or trellis. Harvest daily to encourage continuous production.

facts: A stunning ornamental bean with purple flowers, purple-tinged leaves, and edible young pods, perfect for arbors and trellises.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. Occasional aphids.
growingTip: Provide strong support as vines can reach 10-20 feet. Young pods are edible when harvested small.

facts: Often considered one of the sweetest cherry tomatoes available.
pestsDiseases: Hornworms, early/late blight, blossom end rot.
growingTip: Consistent watering is key to prevent cracking and blossom end rot.

facts: A prolific cherry tomato that produces clusters of 100+ sweet, bite-sized fruits with excellent disease resistance.
pestsDiseases: Generally disease resistant. Watch for hornworms and late blight.
growingTip: Provide strong support as plants can grow 6+ feet tall. Harvest regularly to encourage production.

facts: A unique heirloom tomato with green skin striped with yellow when ripe, offering a tangy, slightly tart flavor that's perfect for salads.
pestsDiseases: Hornworms, early/late blight, blossom end rot.
growingTip: Harvest when fruits have yellow stripes and give slightly to pressure. Great for adding color to salads.

facts: A stunning heirloom tomato with multicolored fruits featuring red, yellow, and green streaks that create a tie-dye pattern, with exceptional sweet flavor.
pestsDiseases: Hornworms, early/late blight, blossom end rot.
growingTip: Harvest when fruits show full color development. Each fruit has a unique pattern - no two are alike!

facts: A legendary heirloom beefsteak tomato dating to 1885, prized for its exceptional flavor, large size, and pink-red color with outstanding taste.
pestsDiseases: Hornworms, early/late blight, blossom end rot. Somewhat disease susceptible.
growingTip: Requires strong support due to large fruit size. Allow plenty of time to ripen for best flavor development.

facts: A diverse mix of heirloom lettuce varieties perfect for cut-and-come-again harvesting, providing continuous salad greens throughout the season.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, slugs, downy mildew. Bolts quickly in hot weather.
growingTip: Harvest outer leaves regularly to encourage continued growth. Succession plant every 2 weeks for continuous harvest.

facts: A small romaine with a crunchy heart.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, slugs, downy mildew.
growingTip: Grows best in cool weather; provide afternoon shade in summer.

facts: A beautiful butterhead lettuce with green leaves edged in red, combining the best of both romaine and butter lettuce characteristics.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, slugs, downy mildew. Bolts quickly in hot weather.
growingTip: Grow in cool weather for best flavor. Succession plant every 2 weeks for continuous harvest.

facts: Developed at Cornell University, it has about twice the beta-carotene of butternut squash.
pestsDiseases: Squash bugs, vine borers, powdery mildew.
growingTip: Hand-pollinate if fruit set is poor to ensure a good harvest.

facts: A compact bush-type summer squash perfect for small gardens, producing buttery yellow fruits on space-saving plants.
pestsDiseases: Squash bugs, vine borers, powdery mildew.
growingTip: Harvest when fruits are 6-8 inches long for best flavor. Bush type requires no staking or trellising.

facts: An old heirloom from the 1840s, great for cornmeal and flour.
pestsDiseases: Corn earworm, raccoons.
growingTip: Plant in a block of at least 4x4 for successful wind pollination.

facts: A classic yellow sweet corn variety known for its excellent flavor, tender kernels, and reliable performance in various growing conditions.
pestsDiseases: Corn earworm, raccoons, birds.
growingTip: Plant in blocks of at least 4x4 for proper wind pollination. Harvest when kernels are milky and sweet.

facts: A stunning decorative dahlia with large pink blooms that make excellent cut flowers and garden focal points.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, spider mites, powdery mildew. Slugs may damage young growth.
growingTip: Plant tubers after soil warms to 60°F. Stake tall varieties and deadhead for continuous blooms.

facts: A beautiful bicolor dahlia with yellow petals edged in pink, creating a stunning two-toned effect perfect for bouquets.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, spider mites, powdery mildew. Slugs may damage young growth.
growingTip: Plant tubers after soil warms to 60°F. Provide morning sun and afternoon shade in hot climates.

facts: A rare dinner plate dahlia with extraordinary bronze-brown coloring that creates dramatic focal points in gardens and arrangements.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, spider mites, powdery mildew. Slugs may damage young growth.
growingTip: Requires strong staking due to large blooms. Plant in protected area from strong winds.

facts: A vibrant cactus-type dahlia with spiky red petals that create a dramatic, almost flame-like appearance in the garden.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, spider mites, powdery mildew. Slugs may damage young growth.
growingTip: Cactus dahlias have pointed petals that can be damaged by wind. Provide shelter and stake well.

facts: A decorative dahlia with rich purple blooms that provide deep, royal color to garden beds and floral arrangements.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, spider mites, powdery mildew. Slugs may damage young growth.
growingTip: Purple varieties show best color with some afternoon shade in hot climates. Deadhead regularly.

facts: A striking bicolor dahlia with white petals edged in purple, creating an intricate pattern reminiscent of a maze or labyrinth.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, spider mites, powdery mildew. Slugs may damage young growth.
growingTip: Bicolor varieties may show different color patterns depending on temperature. Cooler weather enhances edge coloring.

facts: A compact dahlia with beautiful coral-orange blooms that add warm, tropical colors to gardens and arrangements.
pestsDiseases: Aphids, spider mites, powdery mildew. Slugs may damage young growth.
growingTip: Compact varieties are perfect for containers and front of borders. Less staking required than tall varieties.

facts: A top choice for cut flower growers due to its large blooms and sturdy stems.
pestsDiseases: Powdery mildew is common; ensure good air circulation.
growingTip: Cut deep into the plant to get long stems for bouquets; this encourages more blooms.

facts: A stunning amaranth with deep red plumes that can reach 6 feet tall, producing both ornamental beauty and edible leaves and seeds.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. Occasional aphids on young growth.
growingTip: Direct sow after soil warms. Extremely heat and drought tolerant once established. Harvest young leaves for salads.

facts: A stunning calendula mix with unique bicolor flowers featuring orange and yellow petals with burgundy backs, creating a 'flashback' effect when petals curl.
pestsDiseases: Generally pest-free. May get aphids or powdery mildew in humid conditions.
growingTip: Deadhead regularly to encourage continuous blooming. Petals are edible and great for salads and teas.

facts: A tall mix of hybrid coneflowers in various colors including pink, orange, yellow, and red, creating a vibrant wildflower display.
pestsDiseases: Generally disease resistant. May get powdery mildew in humid conditions.
growingTip: Deadhead spent flowers to encourage more blooms, or leave for birds to enjoy the seeds in fall.

facts: A cross between a lemon and mandarin orange, producing sweet, thin-skinned lemons perfect for cooking and eating fresh.
pestsDiseases: Scale insects, aphids, citrus canker. Root rot in poorly drained soils.
growingTip: Excellent in containers. Bring indoors when temperatures drop below 50°F. Needs consistent moisture but not waterlogged.

facts: Also known as Persian lime, this variety produces large, seedless limes with thick skin and juicy flesh, perfect for cooking and cocktails.
pestsDiseases: Scale insects, aphids, citrus canker. Root rot in poorly drained soils.
growingTip: Thornless variety makes harvesting easier. Excellent in containers. Protect from cold winds and frost.

facts: Blooms start as a lime green, turn to white, and then fade to pink in the fall.
pestsDiseases: Bud blight, leaf spot, rust.
growingTip: Blooms on new wood, so prune in late winter or early spring for best results.
